metadata.title: Engineering electronic structures of nanomaterials towardcarbon dioxide electroreduction

Introduction With accelerated global warming and exhaustion of energy resource caused by the immoderate use of fossil fuels, the conversion of CO2 into valuable chemicals and fuels becomes a promising pathway [1 ,2e4]. In the past few decades, various strategies, such as chemical reforming [5,6], photochemical conversion [7e9], biological conversion [10,11], and electrochemical conversion [12e14], have been developed for CO2 conversion and utilization. Among them, CO2 electroreduction in
www.sciencedirect.com
aqueous solution paves a promising way for green conversion of CO2 because of the environmentally friendly catalytic process under ambient pressure at room temperature [15e18]. Until now, metal-based catalysts such as Cu, Zn, Pd, Ag, Cd, In, Sn, Au, Pb, and Bi have been proved to be helpful toward CO2 electroreduction. Especially, Cu-based catalysts can produce the high valueeadded C2þ products via C-C coupling [19e21]. However, most catalysts are enslaved to lower catalytic activity and product selectivity, which is caused by the thermodynamic stability of CO2 with two equivalent C=O bond energy of 230 kJ/mol. Therefore, the efficient activation of CO2 is still a bottleneck during electroreduction process [22e25].
Engineering electronic structure is well known as an effective way to promote catalytic performance. For example, the manipulation of d-band centers for Pt changed the adsorption energy of O2 on the active Pt sites by alloying, resulting in different performance toward oxygen reduction reaction [26]. Besides, the binding strength between Pt sites and CO over Pt deposited on nanoporous Au catalyst was weakened by lowering the d-band center, thus enhancing the activity toward methanol oxidation reaction [27]. In addition, the abundant electrons on Pd atoms at the vertices of CuPd tetrapods reduced the adsorption energy of O2 on Pd sites because of the sharp-tip effect and electron transfer from Cu to Pd, leading to the enhanced oxygen reduction reaction activity [28]. Moreover, n-type doping of MoS2 nanosheets with Zn dopants shifted the Fermi energy into the conduction band of MoS2, thus modulating the hydrogen evolution activity [29]. Furthermore, the incorporation of P into Ni-based multimetal oxides promoted the oxidation from Ni2þ to Ni4þ which was highly active toward oxygen evolution reaction [30].
Most reviews focused on classifying catalysts based on the type of element or the affinity to different atoms in reactants for CO2 electroreduction [31e33]. Less attention has been paid to the manipulation of electronic structures. Herein, we report the recent progress in CO2 reduction from the perspective of engineering electronic structures of nanocatalysts. As a prerequisite for CO2 electroreduction, CO2 activation is discussed in
Current Opinion in Electrochemistry 2019, 17:7–15
this review. For general regulation strategies, we discuss the vacancy engineering, heteroatom substitution, atomic layer regulation, sharp-tip effect, and interlayer bond length regulation (Figure 1). These strategies promote the activation of CO2 through the construction of defect level, the formation of electron-rich surface, or the manipulation of delocalized electrons for catalysts during CO2 electroreduction process. Finally, we try to predict the trend between the activity of CO2 electroreduction and the electronic structure of catalysts.
Vacancy engineering Vacancy engineering is widely used as an efficient method to regulate surface electronic structure of catalysts. Especially for metal oxides, engineering oxygen vacancy provides a powerful approach to enhance CO2 conversion by promoting CO2 adsorption and activation. For example, oxygen vacancy gave rise to electron trap centers, which made the surface electronic-rich [34 ]. The electronic-rich surface participated in CO2 activation by forming stable adsorption configurations of the C=O bonds, leading to reduced energy barrier of the electron transfer process from CO2 to CO2 - .
It was found that the presence of oxygen vacancies lowered the proton transfer barrier and thus stabilized the formate anion radical intermediate [35]. Hence, vacancy-rich cobalt oxide single-unit-cell layers exhibited a current density of 2.7 mA cm 2 with Faradaic efficiency (FE) of ca. 85% for formate during 40-h tests. Recently, Geng et al. [36] explored CO2 activation via introducing oxygen vacancy into ZnO nanosheets. Density functional theory calculations revealed that a

new defect level appeared around the valence band maximum for the ZnO slab with oxygen vacancy. Besides, in the valence band maximum, ZnO slab with oxygen vacancy accumulated electrons around oxygen vacancy compared with ZnO slab without oxygen vacancy. These abundant localized electrons around the valence band maximum are expected to be transferred into the antibond orbital of CO2. During CO2 reduction, Vo-rich ZnO nanosheets exhibited FE of 83% with current density of 16.1 mA cm 2 for CO production at 1.1 V versus reversible hydrogen electrode (vs RHE) (Figure 2). Double layer capacitances, Nyquist plots, and Tafel slopes analysis were further conducted to investigate the reaction mechanism, wherein the ratelimiting step switched from activation process to surface reaction. This result was also testified by Gibbs free energy calculation and temperature-programmed desorption profiles.
Heteroatom substitution Elemental doping is considered as another efficient way to tailor the electronic structure of catalysts because of the hybridization of energy levels between dopants and pristine catalysts. Especially, heteroatom substitution has been applied to engineer d-band center [37,38], valence state of active site [39,40], and charge redistribution of semiconductors [41] for catalysts, leading to enhanced catalytic performance.
Xu et al. [42] conducted an ideal model of ternary transition-metal dichalcogenides (TMDs) alloy monolayer to explore the intrinsic reason for the promoted electrocatalytic performance of ternary TMDs alloy relative to the two pristine binary TMDs. The substitution of S by Se helped electrons depart fromMo atoms and close to S atoms because of the stronger electronegativity of S than Se. As such, the MoSeS alloy monolayers exhibited a current density of 43 mA cm 2 for CO with the FE of 45.2% at 1.15 V vs RHE. Mechanistic study further revealed that the offcentered charge density of Mo atom in the MoSeS alloy monolayers reduced the overlap between the dorbital of Mo and the p-orbital of Se and the overlap between the d-orbital of Mo and the p-orbital of C in CO*, resulting in stabilized *COOH intermediate and weak CO adsorption. Zhang et al. [43] used Ni dopant to substitute Sn in SnS2 nanosheets. A defect level below the conduction band was found in Ni-doped SnS2 monolayer, leading to the narrowed band gap from 2.3 eV of pristine SnS2 to 1.9 eV of Ni-doped SnS2. They further found that there were abundant electrons in the vicinity of Ni atom, which affected the charge distribution around adjacent Sn, resulting in facile CO2 activation into *HCOO intermediates. Recently, Cudoped CeO2 was developed for selective CO2 electroreduction into CH4 [44]. The lower oxidation of Cu in Cu-doped CeO2 enriched multiple oxygen vacancies

into the neighboring positions, enabling a highly efficient catalytic center for CO2 adsorption and activation. Zhou et al. [45] adopted boron (B) to tune the ratio of Cudþ to Cu0 active sites. The introduction of B dopant on the surfaces of Cu nanoparticles varied the valence states of Cu between Cu0 and Cu1þ, in which Cu0.32þ achieved a high FE value for C2 products of w80%.
Atomic layer regulation Owing to the atomically flat facets, atomic-scale thickness, and ultrahigh specific surface area, atomically-thin two-dimensional (2D) nanosheets are regarded as an ideal platform to gain atomic-level insights into the relationship between active sites and catalysis [46]. The atomically flat facets help us acquire uniform active sites with almost the same coordination number. Meanwhile, the monolayer thickness and ultrahigh electrochemical surface area greatly improve atomic utilization in comparison with bulk samples. In addition, the atoms in the flat facets of the ultrathin two-dimensional sheets could easily migrate from the lattice to form defects which affect the electronic structure of 2D nanosheets, thus altering the intrinsic activity of catalysts.
www.sciencedirect.com
Gao et al. [47] reported ultrathin Co3O4 nanosheets as efficient catalysts toward CO2 electroreduction. They found that the charge density around the conduction band edge in ultrathin Co3O4 layer was higher and more dispersive than that in bulk Co3O4. It was believed that the accumulated electrons were beneficial for faster carrier transport to participate in CO2 activation process. During CO2 electroreduction, Co3O4 layers with thickness of 1.72 nm showed a current density of 0.68 mA cm 2 and a maximum FE of 64.3% at 0.88 V vs saturated calomel electrode. As expected, Co3O4 layers with thickness of 1.72 nm possessed the highest surface area and CO2 adsorption capacity. Meanwhile, the electronic states of Co3O4 layers caused by thickness also switched the rate-limiting step from a fast 1e preequilibrium to an electron transfer and protoncoupling step as the thickness became thinner (Figure 3). Li et al. [48] engineered 2D Sb nanosheets via cathodical exfoliation of bulk Sb crystals. The 2D Sb nanosheets were believed to possess catalytically active edge sites, leading to an evolution from inactive bulk Sb to active 2D Sb nanosheets. What is more, the electronic interaction between 2D Sb nanosheets and graphene modulated the reaction kinetics, resulting in 16 times
Current Opinion in Electrochemistry 2019, 17:7–15
higher activity than bulk Sb for electroreduction CO2 into formate.
Sharp-tip effect Owing to the accumulation of electrons in the tips of sharp-tip structures, branched nanocrystals such as nanoneedles, multipods, and nanodendrites possessed tremendous potential in a rich variety of catalytic reactions. For example, sharp-tip Pt3Co octapods readily transferred electrons into CO2 to form CO2
- intermediates, leading to enhanced performance of CO2 hydrogenation to methanol [49 ]. Besides, the accumulation of electrons may also induce the redistribution of cations in electrolytes, which helps the activation of CO2.
Liu et al. [50] constructed Au needles to explore the field-induced effect for electroreduction CO2 into CO. Based on density functional theory calculation, Kþ acted as a stabilizer for *COOH intermediates and reduced the activation barrier of *COOH. However, activation of CO2 into *COOH was restricted by the low concentration of Kþ in the electrolyte. Simulations suggested that Au needles could concentrate Kþ because of the enhanced electronic field around Helmholtz layer of KHCO3 electrolyte. They also proved that the sharp-tip Au needles induced much higher concentration of Kþ around Helmholtz layer than the increased concentration of KHCO3 electrolyte. During CO2 electroreduction process, the activity normalized by electrochemical surface area of Au needles was 64 times and 113 times as high as that of Au rods and Au nanoparticles (Figure 4). Expanded experiments revealed that Pd needles also possessed the highest performance among Pd needles, rods, and particles toward CO2 electroreduction. Furthermore, the sequential electrodeposition of Au on honed Au needles increased the density of sharp-tip structure into a branched needle [51]. As a result, a new record was created with a geometric current density of 38 mA cm 2 at 0.4 V vs RHE for electroreduction CO2 into CO. In addition, sharp morphologies of electroredeposited Cu depressed methane formation, leading to a partial ethylene current density of 160 mA cm 2 ( 1.0 V vs RHE) and an ethylene/methane ratio of 200 [52]. Except for sharp-tip structure, edge and corner sites of nanosheets with thickness down to nanoscale also possess higher electron density than that of facets. Kim et al. [53] conducted electrodeposited Bi-based electrocatalysts toward CO2 electroreduction. Owing to field-induced increment of local Kþ concentration and enhanced driving force of charges transfer from the catalyst to the electrolyte, Bi nanoflakes with high density of edge and corner sites promoted CO2 electroreduction into formate.
Interlayer bond length regulation Owing to the tunable electronic structure of d-orbitals, transition metals are widely explored in CO2
www.sciencedirect.com
electroreduction process. For example, bimetallic AuCu nanoparticles were used to quantitatively compare activity and selectivity toward CO2 electroreduction, wherein d-band center affected the catalytic activity and selectivity for CO [54]. However, compared with transition metals, main-group metals exhibit p-orbital electronic properties. Thus, the engineering of p-orbital electron states of main-group metals is also critical for catalytic process.
He et al. [55] achieved enhanced activity of CO2 electroreduction into formate by modulating the electronic states of localized p-orbitals into delocalized states for metallic Bi. The delocalized degrees of electronic states increased with the decrement of interlayer Bi-Bi bond length. Owing to the compressed structure, the electronic distribution of interlayer Bi atoms in real space coupled with each other, leading to Bi with the delocalized electrons of p-orbitals. A linear relationship was further achieved between the projected density of state of Bi p-electrons and the adsorption free energy of *HCOO. They further constructed p-orbitaledelocalized Bi catalyst with short interlayer bond length via in situ electrochemical reduction of BiOCl. During electroreduction process, a maximal FE of 95% for formate was obtained over p-orbitaledelocalized Bi at 1.16 V vs RHE with corresponding partial current density of 57 mA cm 2.
Conclusion and perspectives Manipulation of electronic structures plays an irreplaceable role in designing of catalysts toward CO2 electroreduction. In particular, engineering electronic structures deep into the atomic level represents the future tendency for catalysis. To gain deeper insight into the relationship between electronic structure and catalytic performance, more attention should be paid to the following aspects.
It is urgently needed to give a quantitative relationship between electronic structures and catalytic performance. The fundamental effect of the descriptors such as electron density, d-band center, or p-orbital properties on catalytic performance should be well established. A distinct descriptor may provide a guideline to engineer highly efficient nanocatalysts toward CO2 electroreduction.
The strictly controllable structureeproperty relationship should be built and carried forward. Starting from the precisely controllable design of the catalysts, we could construct simplified theoretical models. At the same time, attention should also be paid to the regulation of active sites down to the atomic level. For example, single-atom catalysts can be constructed to improve the utilization of noble metals [56 ,57]. Coordination numbers [58,59 ] and the types of
Current Opinion in Electrochemistry 2019, 17:7–15
coordination atoms [60,61] can also be regulated to tune the electronic structure of single-site catalysts. Furthermore, dimers and trimers can be constructed to investigate interatomic synergy effect.
Current Opinion in Electrochemistry 2019, 17:7–15
In situ [45] and quasi in situ [62] characterization methods should be conducted into catalytic reaction. The characterization of electronic state of the catalysts and reaction intermediate provides essential ways to
www.sciencedirect.com
investigate reaction mechanism [63]. We should enrich characterization methods to provide the necessary experimental evidence for exploring catalytic mechanism and thus manipulating catalytic pathway.

metadata.abstractText: The electroreduction of CO2 into valuable products holds the prospect for the shortage of fossil fuels and global warming. For the design of catalysts, manipulating the electronic structures of catalysts plays a vital role in the adsorption, activation, and desorption behaviors during the catalytic process. Here, we summarize recent progress in CO2 electroreduction from the perspective of engineering electronic structures of catalysts. The strategies include vacancy engineering, heteroatom substitution, atomic layer regulation, sharp-tip effect, and interlayer bond length regulation. Particularly, combining with the experimental and theoretical results reported previously, we provide an atomic-level insight into the effect of electronic structure on CO2 activation. All rights reserved. Introduction With accelerated global warming and exhaustion of energy resource caused by the immoderate use of fossil fuels, the conversion of CO2 into valuable chemicals and fuels becomes a promising pathway [1 ,2e4]. In the past few decades, various strategies, such as chemical reforming [5,6], photochemical conversion [7e9], biological conversion [10,11], and electrochemical conversion [12e14], have been developed for CO2 conversion and utilization. Among them, CO2 electroreduction in www.sciencedirect.com aqueous solution paves a promising way for green conversion of CO2 because of the environmentally friendly catalytic process under ambient pressure at room temperature [15e18]. Until now, metal-based catalysts such as Cu, Zn, Pd, Ag, Cd, In, Sn, Au, Pb, and Bi have been proved to be helpful toward CO2 electroreduction. Especially, Cu-based catalysts can produce the high valueeadded C2þ products via C-C coupling [19e21]. However, most catalysts are enslaved to lower catalytic activity and product selectivity, which is caused by the thermodynamic stability of CO2 with two equivalent C=O bond energy of 230 kJ/mol. Therefore, the efficient activation of CO2 is still a bottleneck during electroreduction process [22e25]. Engineering electronic structure is well known as an effective way to promote catalytic performance. For example, the manipulation of d-band centers for Pt changed the adsorption energy of O2 on the active Pt sites by alloying, resulting in different performance toward oxygen reduction reaction [26]. Besides, the binding strength between Pt sites and CO over Pt deposited on nanoporous Au catalyst was weakened by lowering the d-band center, thus enhancing the activity toward methanol oxidation reaction [27]. In addition, the abundant electrons on Pd atoms at the vertices of CuPd tetrapods reduced the adsorption energy of O2 on Pd sites because of the sharp-tip effect and electron transfer from Cu to Pd, leading to the enhanced oxygen reduction reaction activity [28]. Moreover, n-type doping of MoS2 nanosheets with Zn dopants shifted the Fermi energy into the conduction band of MoS2, thus modulating the hydrogen evolution activity [29]. Furthermore, the incorporation of P into Ni-based multimetal oxides promoted the oxidation from Ni2þ to Ni4þ which was highly active toward oxygen evolution reaction [30]. Most reviews focused on classifying catalysts based on the type of element or the affinity to different atoms in reactants for CO2 electroreduction [31e33]. Less attention has been paid to the manipulation of electronic structures. Herein, we report the recent progress in CO2 reduction from the perspective of engineering electronic structures of nanocatalysts. As a prerequisite for CO2 electroreduction, CO2 activation is discussed in Current Opinion in Electrochemistry 2019, 17:7–15 8 Environmental Electrochemistry this review. For general regulation strategies, we discuss the vacancy engineering, heteroatom substitution, atomic layer regulation, sharp-tip effect, and interlayer bond length regulation (Figure 1). These strategies promote the activation of CO2 through the construction of defect level, the formation of electron-rich surface, or the manipulation of delocalized electrons for catalysts during CO2 electroreduction process. Finally, we try to predict the trend between the activity of CO2 electroreduction and the electronic structure of catalysts. Vacancy engineering Vacancy engineering is widely used as an efficient method to regulate surface electronic structure of catalysts. Especially for metal oxides, engineering oxygen vacancy provides a powerful approach to enhance CO2 conversion by promoting CO2 adsorption and activation. For example, oxygen vacancy gave rise to electron trap centers, which made the surface electronic-rich [34 ]. The electronic-rich surface participated in CO2 activation by forming stable adsorption configurations of the C=O bonds, leading to reduced energy barrier of the electron transfer process from CO2 to CO2 . It was found that the presence of oxygen vacancies lowered the proton transfer barrier and thus stabilized the formate anion radical intermediate [35]. Hence, vacancy-rich cobalt oxide single-unit-cell layers exhibited a current density of 2.7 mA cm 2 with Faradaic efficiency (FE) of ca. 85% for formate during 40-h tests. Recently, Geng et al.
